facts.text: Appeals are Cases Nos. 270 and 271 of 1951 under Article 132 of the Constitution from Madras High Court judgment dated 27th July 1950

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION.--Cases Nos. 270 an d 27 1 of 1951, Appeals under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated 27th July, 1950, of the Madras High Court in certain applications under Art. 226 of the Constitution for protection of the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Art. 15  1  and Art. 29  2  of the Constitution

facts.text: High Court applications under Article 226 for writ of mandamus restraining State of Madras from enforcing Communal G.O. for admissions to Medical and Engineering Colleges

anchor.surface_text: Cases Nos. 270 an d 27 1 of 1951, Appeals under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated 27th July, 1950, of the Madras High Court in certain applications under Art. 226 of the Constitution for protection of the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Art. 15  1  and Art. 29  2  of the Constitution and praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus or other suitable prerogative writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers and subordinates thereof from en- forcing, observing, maintaining or following the order of the Government known as the Communal G.O.

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges with 330 seats available

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges and only 330 seats are available for students in those four Colleges. Out of these 330 seats, 17 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State and 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are apportioned between four distinct groups of districts in the State.

facts.text: Out of 330 medical seats, 17 reserved for students from outside the State, 12 for discretionary allotment by State, balance apportioned between four groups of districts

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 330 seats, 17 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State and 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are apportioned between four distinct groups of districts in the State. Likewise, the State of Madras maintains four Engineer- ing Colleges and the total number of seats available for students in those Colleges are only 395.

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Engineering Colleges with 395 seats available

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, the State of Madras maintains four Engineer- ing Colleges and the total number of seats available for students in those Colleges are only 395. Out of these, 21 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State, 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are appor- tioned between the same four distinct groups of districts.

facts.text: Out of 395 engineering seats, 21 reserved for outside State, 12 discretionary, balance to four district groups

anchor.surface_text: Out of these, 21 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State, 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are appor- tioned between the same four distinct groups of districts. For many years before the companymencement of the Constitu- tion, the seats in both the Medical Colleges and the Engi- neering Colleges so apportioned between the four distinct groups of districts used to be filled up according to cer- tain proportions set forth in what used to be called the Communal G. O.

facts.text: Communal G.O. proportions for every 14 seats: Non-Brahmin Hindus 6, Backward Hindus 2, Brahmins 2, Harijans 2, Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1, Muslims 1

anchor.surface_text: Thus, for every 14 seats to be filled by the selection companymittee, candidates used to be selected strictly on the following basis-- Non-Brahmin  Hindus  6 Backward Hindus 2 Brahmins 2 Harijans 2 Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1 Muslims 1 Subject to the aforesaid regional and what have been claimed to be protective provisions selection from among the applicants from a particular companymunity from one of the groups of districts used to be made on certain principles based on academic qualifications and marks obtained by the candidates.

facts.text: Communal G.O. proportions adhered to even after Constitution commencement on January 26, 1950

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the proportion fixed in the old Communal G.O. has been adhered to even after the companymencement of the Constitution on Janu- ary 26, 1950. Indeed, G.O. No. 2208, dated June 16, 1950, laying down rules for the selection of candidates for admis- sion into the Medical Colleges substantially reproduces the companymunal proportion fixed in the old Communal G.O.

facts.text: G.O. No. 2208 dated June 16, 1950 reproduces communal proportions for Medical Colleges

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, G.O. No. 2208, dated June 16, 1950, laying down rules for the selection of candidates for admis- sion into the Medical Colleges substantially reproduces the companymunal proportion fixed in the old Communal G.O. On June 7, 1950, Srimathi Champakam Doratrajan made an application to the High Court of Judicature at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution for protection of her funda- mental rights under article 15  1  and article 29  2  of the Constitution

facts.text: Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan filed application to Madras High Court on June 7, 1950 under Article 226 against Communal G.O. for Medical Colleges

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1950, Srimathi Champakam Doratrajan made an application to the High Court of Judicature at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution for protection of her funda- mental rights under article 15  1  and article 29  2  of the Constitution and prayed for the issue of a writ of mandamus or other suitable prerogative writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers and subordinates thereof from en- forcing, observing, maintaining or following or requiring the enforcement, observance, maintenance or following by the authorities companycerned of the numberification or order generally referred to as the Communal G.O.

facts.text: Champakam Dorairajan did not actually apply for admission to Medical College but knew she would not be admitted as Brahmin community

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavit filed in support of her petition, it does number appear that the petitioner had actually applied for admission in the Medical College. She states that on inquiry she came to know that she would number be admitted to the College as she belonged to the Brahmin companymunity.

facts.text: High Court allowed Champakam Dorairajan's application by judgment on July 27, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment deliv- ered on July 27, 1950, allowed this application of Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan. The State of Madras has number companye up before us on appeal which has been numbered Case No. 270 of 1951.

facts.text: C.R. Srinivasan applied for admission to Government Engineering College at Guindy

anchor.surface_text: Sri Srinivasan who had actually applied for admission into the Government Engineering College at Guindy, filed a petition praying for a writ of mandamus or any other writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers thereof from enforcing, observing, maintaining or following the Communal G.O.

facts.text: C.R. Srinivasan passed Intermediate Examination in March 1950 in first class with 369 marks out of 450 in optionals

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed in support of his petition, the petitioner has stated that he had passed the Intermediate Examination held in March, 1950, in Group 1, passing the said examination in the first class and obtain- ing marks set out in paragraph 1 of his affidavit. It will appear that in the optionals which are taken into companysidera- tion in determining the academic test for admission in the Engineering College the petitioner Srinivasan secured 369 marks out of a maximum of 450 marks.

facts.text: High Court allowed C.R. Srinivasan's application by same judgment on July 27, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has by the same judgment allowed this application also and the State has filed an appeal which has been numbered 271 of 1951.

facts.text: State conceded that both applicants would have been admitted if selections made on merits alone

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel appearing for the State of Madras companyceded that these two applicants would have been admitted to the educational institutions they intended to join and they would number have been denied admission if selections had been made on merits alone.

facts.text: For many years before Constitution, seats filled according to Communal G.O.

anchor.surface_text: For many years before the companymencement of the Constitu- tion, the seats in both the Medical Colleges and the Engi- neering Colleges so apportioned between the four distinct groups of districts used to be filled up according to cer- tain proportions set forth in what used to be called the Communal G. O.

facts.text: Not less than 20% of seats in Medical Colleges filled by women candidates separately for each region

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the Medical Colleges, number less than 20 per cent. of the total number of seats available for students of the State were filled by women candidates separately for each region, it being open to the selection companymittee to admit a larger number of woman candidates in any region if qualified candidates were available in that region and if they were eligible for selection on merits visa vis the men candidates in accordance with the general principles governing such admissions as laid down in those rules.

facts.text: State agreed to reserve a seat for Champakam Dorairajan if her HC application succeeds

anchor.surface_text: No objection, however, was taken to the maintainability of her petition on the ground of absence of any actual application for admission made by her. On the companytrary, we have been told that the State had agreed to reserve a seat for her, should her application before the High Court succeed.

facts.text: Srinivasan secured more marks than many Non-Brahmin candidates selected

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is number disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the Non-Brahmin candidates and yet the Non-Brahmin candidates who secured less number of marks will be admitted into six out of every 14 seats but the petitioner Srinivasan will number be admitted into any ,of them.

issues.text: Whether directive principles of State policy in Part IV can override fundamental rights in Part III of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We reject the above contentions completely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

issues.text: Whether Article 29(2) guarantees a fundamental right to an individual citizen for admission to State-maintained or aided educational institutions not to be denied only on grounds of religion, race, caste or language

No citizen shall be denied admission into any educa- tional institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

He urges that article 46 charges the State with promoting with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and with protecting them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

arguments.claim: State entitled to maintain Communal G.O. fixing proportionate seats for communities pursuant to Article 46

arguments.court_reasoning: Communal G.O. violates Article 29(2); directives subsidiary to fundamental rights

arguments.claim: Article 29(2) guarantees individual citizen's right to admission not to be denied only on grounds of religion, race, caste, language

anchor.surface_text: Article 29 which occurs in Part III of the Constitution under the head Cultural and Educational Rights runs as follows Any section of the citizens residing in the territo- ry of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to con- serve the same. No citizen shall be denied admission into any educa- tional institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

arguments.claim: Right under Article 29(2) is personal to individual citizen, not as member of community

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that while clause  1  protects the language, script or culture of a section of the citizens, clause  2  guarantees the fundamental right of an individual citizen. The right to get admission into any educational institution of the kind mentioned in clause  2  is a right which an individual citizen has as a citizen and number as a member of any companymunity or class of citizens.

arguments.claim: Directive principles in Part IV cannot override fundamental rights in Part III

anchor.surface_text: We reject the above numbered companytentions companypletely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, numberwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

arguments.claim: Omission of provision like Article 16(4) in Article 29 significant; no communal reservations permitted in educational admissions

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it will be numbericed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment... also includes a specif- ic clause... If the arguments founded on article 46 were sound then clause  4 of article 16 would have been wholly unnecessary and redundant. Seeing, however, that clause  4  was inserted in article 16, the omission of such an express provision from article 29 cannot but be regarded as significant.

arguments.claim: Denial of admission to Srinivasan despite higher marks than selected Non-Brahmin candidates solely due to caste constitutes discrimination under Article 15(1) and 29(2)

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is number disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the Non-Brahmin candidates and yet the Non-Brahmin candidates who secured less number of marks will be admitted into six out of every 14 seats but the petitioner Srinivasan will number be admitted into any ,of them.

arguments.claim: Petitioners denied admission not solely because they are Brahmins but due to filled Brahmin quota and other reasons

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that the petitioners are number denied admis- sion only because they are Brahmins but for a variety of reasons, e.g.,  a  they are Brahmins,  b  Brah- mins have an allotment of only two seats out of 14 and  c  the two seats have already been filled up by more meritori- ous Brahmin candidates.

arguments.court_reasoning: True for Brahmin seats but no force for other communities' seats where denial solely on caste ground

arguments.claim: Classification in Communal G.O. based on religion, race and caste violates constitutional prohibitions

anchor.surface_text: The classification in the Communal G.O. proceeds on the basis of religion, race and caste. In our view, the classi- fication made in the Communal G.O.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court rejects State's appeals and confirms violation of fundamental rights

arguments.claim: Applicants would have been admitted if selections made on merits alone

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel appearing for the State of Madras companyceded that these two applicants would have been admitted to the educational institutions they intended to join and they would number have been denied admission if selections had been made on merits alone.

holdings.text: The directive principles of State policy cannot override the provisions found in Part III of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We reject the above contentions completely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 37 expressly makes directive principles unenforceable by courts while Part III rights are enforceable under Article 32; Fundamental Rights are sacrosanct and directive principles must conform to them.

holdings.text: Article 29(2) guarantees the fundamental right of an individual citizen to admission in state educational institutions, not to be denied only on grounds of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

anchor.surface_text: Article 29 which occurs in Part III of the Constitution under the head Cultural and Educational Rights runs as follows Any section of the citizens residing in the territo- ry of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to con- serve the same. No citizen shall be denied admission into any educa- tional institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes clause (1) for sections from clause (2) for individual citizens; right personal, not communal.

holdings.text: The omission of a provision in Article 29 similar to Article 16(4) permitting reservations for backward classes is significant and indicates no communal reservations permitted in educational admissions.

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it will be noticed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment and provides that no citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State also includes a specif- ic clause

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 16(4) expressly allows reservations in employment for backward classes despite general prohibition; deliberate omission in Article 29 precludes such in education.

holdings.text: The Communal G.O. infringes Article 15(1) and Article 29(2) by denying admission solely on grounds of caste despite superior merit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Article 29(2) to facts: superior marks but denial due to Brahmin caste, while lower-marked others admitted under quota.

holdings.text: The Communal G.O. for Engineering Colleges infringes Article 15(1) and Article 29(2) in the same manner.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same proportions and principles apply to engineering seats; Srinivasan example illustrates caste-based denial.

holdings.text: Provisions of Article 46 do not permit reading Article 29(2) subject to it to allow communal reservations.

anchor.surface_text: No objection, however, was taken to the maintainability of her petition on the ground of absence of any actual application for admission made by her. holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter dictum; matter not pursued as State conceded and reserved seat, but disapproval expressed.

anchor.surface_text: We reject the above contentions completely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

We reject the above contentions completely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unenforceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

Article 29 which occurs in Part III of the Constitution under the head Cultural and Educational Rights runs as follows Any section of the citizens residing in the territo- ry of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to con- serve the same. No citizen shall be denied admission into any educa- tional institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

We reject the above contentions completely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unenforceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

In the next place, it will be noticed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment and provides that no citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State also includes a specif- ic clause
